answer: Minerals present in the body in larger amounts.

title: Nutrition
question: Trace minerals
answer: Minerals present in small amounts in the body. They include iron, zinc, copper, selenium, iodine, manganese, chromium, fluoride, and molybdenum.

title: Nutrition
question: Heat exhaustion
answer: A condition that occurs when the body becomes overheated. It can occur from dehydration in a hot climate, and symptoms include heavy sweating, rapid pulse, low blood pressure, nausea, dizziness, and muscle cramps.

title: Nutrition
question: Heatstroke
answer: A condition that can develop if heat exhaustion is not treated quickly. Heatstroke symptoms include headache, fever, confusion and disorientation, and flushed skin. Heatstroke is a medical emergency and can be fatal if not quickly treated.

title: Nutrition
question: Sports drink
answer: Drink with a combination of carbohydrate and/or electrolytes used for rehydration and carbohydrate replenishment during physical activity; may be isotonic, hypotonic, or hypertonic.

title: Nutrition
question: Hypotonic
answer: A solution with a lower solute load/concentration than body fluids.

title: Nutrition
question: Isotonic
answer: A solution with a similar solute load/concentration as body fluids.

title: Nutrition
question: Hypertonic
answer: A solution with a higher solute load/concentration than body fluids.

title: Nutrition
question: Endocrine (hormonal) disorders
answer: When the body produces too little or too much of an endocrine hormone.

title: Nutrition
question: Added sugars
answer: Sugars that are not naturally found in food but have been added to a food product.

title: Nutrition
question: Satiating
answer: Satisfying; feeling of fullness.

title: Nutrition
question: Peptide YY
answer: Called peptide tyrosine and is a peptide that is released in the colon during feeding.

title: Nutrition
question: Ghrelin
answer: The hunger hormone that stimulates appetite.

title: Nutrition
question: Hypothyroidism
answer: Low activity of the thyroid gland that can disrupt heart rate, body temperature, and metabolism.

title: Nutrition
question: Cushing's syndrome
answer: A hormone disorder that causes abnormally high levels of cortisol in the body.

title: Nutrition
question: Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
answer: A hormone disorder that occurs in women of childbearing age that causes irregular periods, excess levels of the male hormone androgen, small cysts on the outer edges of the ovaries, and obesity.

title: Nutrition
question: Adaptive thermogenesis
answer: Metabolic adaptations and changes in energy expenditure as a result of changes in energy intake.

title: Nutrition
question: Ingredients list
answer: A list of all included ingredients in a food product, in descending order of amount by weight, on a food label.

title: Nutrition
question: Nutrition facts panel
answer: Label on food products that provides information on the nutrient content of the food. Lists servings per container, serving size, and the amount of specific nutrients.

title: Nutrition
question: Serving size
answer: A reference amount based on the quantity of the product consumers are thought to typically consume at one sitting.

title: Nutrition
question: Percent daily value (%DV)
answer: A reference value on the nutrition label that indicates what percentage of the recommended daily value for a nutrient is met by the specified serving size of a food product, based on a 2,000-calorie diet.

title: Nutrition
question: Percent reference intake (% RI)
answer: Used on food labels in the United Kingdom and the European Union. It is a reference value that indicates what percentage of the recommend amount of a nutrient is met by the specified amount (100 g or 100 mL) of the food product.

title: Nutrition
question: Hypertrophy
answer: Enlargement of an organ or tissue; in the context of fitness, it is often used to describe the enlargement of skeletal muscle.

title: Supplementation
question: Dietary supplement
answer: A product (other than tobacco) intended to supplement the diet that bears or contains one or more of the following dietary ingredients: vitamin; mineral; herb or other botanical; amino acid; substance used by man to supplement the diet by increasing the total dietary intake; or concentrate, metabolite, constituent, extract, or combination of any previously described ingredient.

title: Supplementation
question: Essential nutrient
answer: Must be obtained in the diet, as the body is incapable of producing the nutrient on its own.

title: Supplementation
question: Toxicity
answer: When too much of a vitamin or mineral accumulates within the body, resulting in illness or other symptoms.

title: Supplementation
question: Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994
answer: The primary legislation of the U.S. government regulating dietary supplements.

title: Supplementation
question: Code of Federal Regulations
answer: Describes the laws and regulations for dietary supplements, including how supplements are labeled, manufactured, and brought to or removed from market.

title: Supplementation
question: Tolerable upper limit
answer: The greatest quantity of a vitamin or mineral that may be consumed in a day without risk of an adverse health effect.

title: Supplementation
question: Adverse effect
answer: Any unfavorable medical occurrence associated with the use of a medication, medical intervention, or dietary supplement.

title: Supplementation
question: Stimulant
answer: An agent that increases physiologic or metabolic activity. Common stimulants include caffeine and nicotine.

title: Supplementation
question: Creatine
answer: Molecule made from amino acids and used as a dietary supplement to facilitate adenosine triphosphate regeneration for improved training capacity, strength, power, and muscle mass.

title: Supplementation
question: Banned
answer: A dietary supplement that may be prohibited from use in a specific sport or sport league. These supplements may not be illegal or prohibited at all times during the year.

title: Supplementation
question: Anabolic steroid
answer: Compound made from testosterone or another hormone that acts on hormone receptors to produce increases in muscle size or strength.

title: Supplementation
question: Active ingredient
answer: Any component of a dietary supplement included for the purpose of causing a physiologic effect; displayed on the main body of the supplement facts panel.

title: Supplementation
question: Other ingredient
answer: Any component of a dietary supplement included for taste, bulk, or as a preservative; displayed beneath the main body of the supplement facts panel.

title: Supplementation
question: Supplement facts panel
answer: Portion of a dietary supplement’s label that displays the active ingredients, other ingredients, serving size, number of servings, quantity of ingredients, and the percent daily value.

title: Supplementation
question: Daily value (DV)
answer: Amount of a nutrient recommended to be consumed each day to maintain good health. Based on a 2,000-calorie diet for those ages 4 years and older.

title: Supplementation
question: Health supplement
answer: A dietary supplement used to improve a component of well-being.

title: Supplementation
question: Performance supplement
answer: A dietary supplement that may enhance performance or body composition; may also be referred to as an ergogenic aid.

title: Supplementation
question: Biologically active
answer: The form in which a vitamin must be to exert an effect within the body.

title: Supplementation
question: Biologically inactive
answer: Any form of vitamin that cannot exert its effect within the body.

title: Supplementation
question: Beta-carotene
answer: The red-orange pigment found in vegetables and fruits that is converted to vitamin A in the body.

title: Supplementation
question: Lactose intolerance
answer: A sensitivity to lactose (milk sugar) typically resulting in gastrointestinal distress.

title: Supplementation
question: Irritable bowel syndrome
answer: Gastrointestinal discomfort, sometimes severe, triggered by certain foods but is not a food allergy.

title: Supplementation
question: Rickets
answer: A bone weakness disease caused by vitamin D deficiency.

title: Supplementation
question: Heart arrhythmias
answer: Irregular heartbeat.

title: Supplementation
question: Platelet aggregation
answer: An accumulation of blood cells prior to a clot.

title: Supplementation
question: Immunodeﬁciency
answer: A weakened immune system.

title: Supplementation
question: Peripheral neuropathy
answer: Nerve damage not occurring in the brain or spinal cord.

title: Supplementation
question: Skeletal myopathy
answer: Muscle degeneration.

title: Supplementation
question: Scurvy
answer: A disease resulting from insufficient vitamin C and characterized by spontaneous bleeding (usually of the gums), anemia, swelling, weakened joints, and loss of teeth.

title: Supplementation
question: Beriberi
answer: A thiamine deficiency that can result in inflammation or degeneration of the heart and nerves, peripheral neuropathy, and impaired motor function.

title: Supplementation
question: Pellagra
answer: A niacin or tryptophan deficiency that leads to a skin rash (dermatitis), digestive disorders (diarrhea), and mood or cognitive decline (dementia).

title: Supplementation
question: Anorexia
answer: A loss of appetite or the conscious decision to avoid eating, often leading to dangerously low body weight and/or malnourishment.

title: Supplementation
question: Anemia
answer: A condition of poor iron status.

title: Supplementation
question: Dermatitis
answer: Inflammation of the skin, rashes, excessive dryness, and/or blistering.

title: Supplementation
question: Spina biﬁda
answer: A birth defect, and type of neural tube defect, when the spine and spinal cord do not form properly.

title: Supplementation
question: Amenorrheic
answer: Absence of menstruation.

title: Supplementation
question: Osteopenia
answer: Lower than normal bone density and a precursor to osteoporosis.

title: Supplementation
question: Lacto-ovo vegetarian
answer: A vegetarian diet that also includes dairy and eggs.

title: Supplementation
question: Ovo-vegetarian
answer: A vegetarian diet that also includes eggs.

title: Supplementation
question: Hypercalcemia
answer: Excess blood calcium levels.

title: Supplementation
question: Heme
answer: A type of iron found in animal foods.

title: Supplementation
question: Nonheme
answer: A type of iron found in plant foods.

title: Supplementation
question: Hemochromatosis
answer: A disease in which the body absorbs too much iron from consumed foods.

title: Supplementation
question: Omega-3
answer: The polyunsaturated fats, eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), and alpha-linolenic acid (ALA).

title: Supplementation
question: Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA)
answer: A type of omega-3 fatty acid found in the flesh of cold-water fish, such as tuna, mackerel, salmon, and herring.

title: Supplementation
question: Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA)
answer: A type of omega-3 fatty acid that is found in seafood, such as fish and fish oils.

title: Supplementation
question: Alpha-linolenic acid (ALA)
answer: One type of omega-3 fatty acid found in seeds and oils, such as walnuts and flaxseed, and many common vegetable oils.

title: Supplementation
question: Ergogenic aid
answer: A dietary supplement that may enhance performance or body composition; it may also be referred to as a performance supplement.

title: Supplementation
question: Branched chain amino acids  (BCAAs)
answer: The three essential amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine) that are abundant in skeletal muscle tissue and named for their branchlike structures.

title: Supplementation
question: Muscle protein synthesis (MPS)
answer: Process by which new muscle proteins are formed and a muscle grows or repairs at the molecular level.

title: Supplementation
question: Phosphagen
answer: High-energy molecule that releases energy when its bonds are broken.

title: Supplementation
question: Creatine monohydrate
answer: The most common, and likely most effective, form of creatine available as a dietary supplement.

title: Supplementation
question: Loading
answer: Practice of using large doses of a supplement to saturate muscle tissues or other body stores prior to resorting to a lesser, maintenance dose.

title: Supplementation
question: Endogenous
answer: Produced or synthesized within an organism.

title: Supplementation
question: Adrenaline
answer: Hormone, also known as epinephrine, that excites bodily processes, increasing alertness and cell metabolism.

title: Supplementation
question: Caffeine anhydrous
answer: A highly concentrated caffeine powder made from the seeds and leaves of coffee plants.

title: Supplementation
question: DMAA
answer: Dimethylamylamine; a stimulant and amphetamine once legal for use as a dietary supplement.

title: Supplementation
question: Ephedra
answer: A plant-sourced alkaloid with metabolism-enhancing effects. It is an illegal supplement in the United States and the European Union.

title: Supplementation
question: Serious adverse effect
answer: Any adverse effect that results in any life-threatening situation, inpatient hospitalization, persistent incapacity of a person’s ability to conduct a normal life, a congenital anomaly, reproductive harm, or death.

title: Supplementation
question: Hormone precursor
answer: A hormone used to create another hormone or hormone-like agent.

title: Supplementation
question: Gynecomastia
answer: A condition in males characterized by breast tissue growth.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Health risk assessment (HRA)
answer: A screening tool used to evaluate the benefits and the risks associated with starting any type of exercise that is strenuous in nature.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Contraindication
answer: A specific situation where a medication, procedure, or exercise should be avoided because it may prove to be harmful to the individual.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Physical Activity Readiness Questionnaire (PAR-Q+)
answer: A detailed questionnaire designed to assess an individual’s physical readiness to engage in structured exercise.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: False-positive screenings
answer: A screening where the results of the health risk assessment might indicate a need for medical clearance, when one is in fact not needed.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Health history questionnaire (HHQ)
answer: A questionnaire with lists of questions that pertain to health history and habits, such as exercise history, eating behaviors, and general lifestyle.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Thermoregulation
answer: The physiological process by which the body maintains a relatively constant internal body temperature, including events like sweating to cool the body and shivering to warm the body.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Peripheral vasodilation
answer: The action of expanding the diameter of a blood vessel near the surface of the skin, which helps remove heat from the body.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Diastolic blood pressure (DBP)
answer: The pressure in arteries and other blood vessels when heart is at rest or between beats; the second (bottom) number recorded.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Arterial system
answer: The system of arteries carrying blood away from the heart.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Brachial artery
answer: The primary artery of the upper arm, which is often used as a site for measuring blood pressure.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Anthropometry
answer: The field of study of the measurement of living humans for purposes of understanding human physical variation in size, weight, and proportion.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Body mass index (BMI)
answer: The measurement of a person’s weight relative to his or her height, which is used to estimate the risks of obesity.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Circumference measurement
answer: The measurement that determines the overall dimension (girth) of a body segment, which can be used to estimate body composition or the prevalence of obesity.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Waist circumference
answer: A measurement that represents the narrowest circumference taken around the midline of the body at the approximate height of the umbilicus (belly button).

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Waist-to-hip ratio (WHR)
answer: The relative score expressing the ratio of the waist circumference to the hip circumference, which correlates to the risk for developing cardiovascular disease.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Gluteal fold
answer: The area where the fold of the buttocks joins the back of the thigh.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Skinfold measurements
answer: A technique used to estimate body fat in which calipers are used to pinch the skin in certain areas of the body.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Jackson and Pollock 7-Site protocol
answer: Measures the thickness of skinfolds at seven different places within the body to estimate body fat percentage.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Jackson and Pollock 3-Site protocol
answer: Measures the thickness of skinfolds at three different places within the body to estimate body fat percentage.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Four-site Durnin– Womersley protocol
answer: Measures the thickness of skinfolds at four different places (biceps, triceps, subscapular, and suprailiac) within the body to estimate body fat percentage.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Bioelectrical impedance analysis (BIA)
answer: A body composition assessment technique that estimates body fat percentage by measuring the resistance to the flow of electrical currents introduced into the body.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Archimedes’ principle
answer: The assumption stating that the volume of fluid displaced is equivalent to the volume of an object fully immersed in that fluid or to the specific fraction of the volume below the surface.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Cardiorespiratory ﬁtness
answer: The ability of the circulatory and respiratory systems to provide the body with oxygen during activity.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Cardiorespiratory assessments
answer: Protocols intended to measure the aerobic fitness of an individual.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: YMCA 3-minute step test
answer: An aerobic test that measures the cardiovascular fitness of an individual based on a 3-minute bout of stair-stepping at a specific cadence.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Recovery heart rate (RHR)
answer: The number of heartbeats measured after exercise ceases, which provides some indication of an individual’s fitness level (i.e., more conditioned people recover more rapidly).

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Rockport walk test
answer: An aerobic test for deconditioned individuals or those of low fitness levels in which they are instructed to walk as fast as possible and have their pulse taken immediately after completing 1 mile.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: 1.5-mile (2.4 km) run test
answer: An aerobic test that measures cardiorespiratory endurance by having the participant cover the distance of 1.5 miles in as short a time as possible.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Talk test
answer: An aerobic test that measures the participant’s ability to talk or hold a conversation during an activity at various intensity levels.

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Steady-state (SS) heart rate
answer: Any stage at which the physiological response of heart rate from the cardiovascular system becomes relatively constant in relation to the amount of work being performed (i.e., the heart rate response matches the level of work being performed).

title: Health, Wellness, and Fitness Assessments
question: Anaerobic energy systems
answer: Energy systems used to perform work in which glycogen is converted to glucose and oxygen is insufficient to break down pyruvate and create adenosine triphosphate.
